title: Financial Boundaries
description: Assess how well you navigate financial boundaries

questions.text: I feel comfortable setting financial boundaries in our relationship.

therapeutic.rationale: Financial boundaries—what you're willing to spend, share, or commit to—protect your wellbeing. Comfort setting them indicates a healthy dynamic.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner is uncomfortable setting boundaries, explore what makes it hard. Fear of conflict? Feeling selfish? These can be addressed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared comfort with boundaries creates space for honest financial communication.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What financial boundaries are important to you? Have you communicated them?

questions.text: I trust my partner respects my financial boundaries.

therapeutic.rationale: Trust that your boundaries will be respected is essential. Partners who feel their limits are ignored experience resentment and withdrawal.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel their boundaries are respected, specific examples help. What boundaries have been crossed?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual trust in boundary respect creates safety in your financial relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Have your financial boundaries been respected? Which ones matter most?

questions.text: I feel we navigate financial decisions involving family well.

therapeutic.rationale: Financial decisions involving extended family—gifts, loans, support—require careful navigation. Feeling good about how you handle these indicates healthy boundaries.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different experiences with family financial decisions often reflect different family pressures. Discuss what each family expects.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of navigating family finances well creates unified approach to boundary-setting.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you handle financial requests or expectations from family?

questions.text: I believe we can say no to financial pressures together.

therapeutic.rationale: Confidence in saying no together—to purchases, requests, social pressures—reflects partnership strength. United boundaries are easier to maintain.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doubts your ability to say no together, explore what creates that doubt. Past experiences? Different pressure tolerances?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence in saying no together creates a united front against financial pressure.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What financial pressures do you face? Can you resist them together?

questions.text: I feel our financial boundaries protect rather than restrict us.

therapeutic.rationale: Healthy boundaries feel protective, not restrictive. When financial limits feel like deprivation rather than wisdom, resentment builds.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner feels restricted rather than protected, explore what would help. Are the boundaries too tight? Not explained well?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense that boundaries are protective creates positive feelings about financial limits.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do your financial boundaries feel helpful or limiting? What would shift that?
